title: Western Electric Company is formed by Enos Barton and Elisha Gray 1872 Bell’s School of Vocal Physiology set up 1877 Bell Telephone Company formed 1879 Bell Telephone Company merges with the New England Telephone Company to become National Bell Telephone Company 1880 National Bell Telephone Company becomes American Bell Telephone Company
Bell receives Volta prize from the French government and sets up Volta Laboratory 1880 Bell Telephone Company of Canada incorporated
American Bell Telephone Company does a reverse merger with its supplier Western Electric Company 1883 Bell starts Science magazine
American Telephone and Telegraph Company (AT&T) incorporated as a subsidiary of American Bell Telephone Company to operate the long-distance telephone network
Bell becomes president of the “National Geographic Society
Volta Laboratory transfers the Phonograph patents to the American Gramophone Company, later to evolve into Columbia Records
1895 Bell Telephone Company of Canada spins off its manufacturing to the Northern Electric and Manufacturing Company Ltd
AT&T becomes the mother company of the Bell System including the various operators later to be called “Baby Bells
AT&T’s Engineering Department merged with Western Electric Research Department to form Bell Telephone Laboratories Inc

container-title: sold to International Telephone & Telegraph Corporation (IT&T
title: International Western Electric Company (a subsidiary of Western Electric
AT&T controls 80 percent of all telephone connections, 98 percent of all long-distance phone lines, and 90 percent of all telephone equipment sold in the United States

note: acquires Northern Electric 1976 Northern Electric renamed as Northern Telecom
title: After an antitrust ruling, AT&T sells its stake in Northern Electric to Bell Canada 1964
After the demerger, AT&T becomes AT&T Technologies

container-title: Name subsequently changed to Alcatel Alsthom
title: IT&T sells its European telecommunications business to Companie General d’Electricite
AT&T Technologies spins off its manufacturing into Lucent Technologies. Most of Bell Laboratories work transferred to Lucent
Northern Telecom becomes Nortel Networks 1998 Alcatel Alsthom’s name changed to Alcatel
Business Communications division of AT&T Technologies spun off as “Avaya
Alcatel and Lucent merge to form Alcatel-Lucent
Nortel Networks files for bankruptcy. Ericsson picks up most of its telecom assets
